Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative research: Automated and community-driven synthesis of the tree of life
Award.AbstractNarration:
The tree of life links all biodiversity through a shared evolutionary history. This project will produce the first online, comprehensive first-draft tree of all 1.8 million named species, accessible to both the public and scientific communities. Assembly of the tree will incorporate previously published results, with strong collaborations between computational and empirical biologists to develop, test and improve methods of data synthesis. This initial tree of life will not be static; instead, we will develop tools for scientists to update and revise the tree as new data come in. Early release of the tree and tools will motivate data sharing and facilitate ongoing synthesis of knowledge.

Biological research of all kinds, including studies of ecological health, environmental change, and human disease, increasingly depends on knowing how species are related to each other. Yet there is no single resource that unites knowledge of the tree of life. Instead, only small parts of the tree are individually available, generally as printed figures in journal articles. This project will provide the global community of scientists who study the tree of life with a means to share and combine their results, and will enable large-scale studies of Earth's biodiversity. It will also create a resource where students, educators and citizens can go to explore and learn about life's evolutionary history.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As part of the Open Tree of Life project, researchers from the University of Florida contributed to a multi-institutional effort to construct a tree of life describing the relationships among ~2.3 million named species. This project produced the OpenTree software that enables researchers to update and revise the tree as new species are named or discovered, greatly increasing the speed with which new species can be placed in context of the entire tree of life. The Burleigh lab worked to develop methods to synthesize phylogenetic trees to build larger, more comprehensive trees that encompass more biodiversity than has been done previously. Methods to assess the quality of estimates of the tree of life, which are important to ensure that big trees are meaningful, was also part of the Burleigh lab.  They also worked on large-scale comparative experiments that used the tree of life, including specific analyses of plant and bird evolution. The Soltis group helped produce the first draft tree of all named species, focusing on the large component of the tree that includes the green plants.

OpenTree provided a community resource that can synthesize knowledge about the evolutionary relationships from all species, including things as diverse as single-celled bacteria to complex, multi-cellular species such as humans. Having a tree of life can help researchers studying diverse disciplines related to biodiversity, including evolution, ecology, agriculture, and medicine. This work also highlighted the amount that is unknown about many diverse forms of life. The Open Tree of Life Project also raised awareness about the tree of life among non-specialists, educators, students, and the general public. That trees are easy to visualize makes them excellent approaches to share and explain biodiversity to non-specialists. Some of this research has formed the basis of ongoing efforts to work with artists and others to find more ways of sharing the evolving and growing tree of life with the public. Additionally, this project and helped to train four postdoctoral researchers and two undergraduates.
